newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Midwest hogs called $0.50-$1.00 lower-private.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Midwest hogs called $0.50-$1.00 lower-private.

text.p: U.S. Midwest direct cash hog prices were called $0.50 to $1.00 per cwt lower Friday on ideas lower wholesale cash pork prices will curb packer demand for hogs, livestock dealers and packer buyers said.
In its carlot report near midday, USDA said hams sold steady to $1.00 per cwt lower and pork bellies, $2.00 lower. Trimmings values also dipped.

The lower pork prices further eroded meat packers' earnings and will likely discourage Saturday slaughter operations, dealers said. Also, since most packers appear to have enough hogs for Friday's slaughter, buyers should be able to buy the few they do need at lower prices.
"We are going to be at least $1.00 lower tomorrow," a southern Minnesota dealer said.
Indiana sources expected $0.50 lower prices for the same reasons.
"We essentially will be out of the market Friday. Friday's kill is satisfied," said the dealer, who expected no Saturday slaughter in his area.
